Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will make a statement giving details of any guarantees, undertakings or promises he has entered into with any Member of this Dail since the general election in relation to the urgently needed upgrading and improvement in hospital services in County Roscommon, in relation to the County Hospital in Roscommon town, the Sacred Heart Geriatric Care Hospital in Roscommon and St. Patrick's Psychiatric Hospital, Castlerea.

asked the Minister for Health if he will give details of any understanding or agreement between himself and Deputy Tom Foxe in recent weeks in securing his support on the election of Taoiseach; the consultations, if any, which took place with the various health authorities; if he will give an assurance that the effect of any such deal will not be to diminish acute hospital facilities elsewhere in the region; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 70 and 71 together.

Deputy Foxe had discussions during which he made his views known with regard to certain hospital services in County Roscommon. The acute medical and surgical services will be continued at Roscommon County Hospital and, as already planned, services there will be enhanced by the location at the hospital of the acute psychiatric unit for the county. Services at Castlerea Psychiatric Hospital will be continued for as long as it is necessary to do so.

I am meeting the Chairman and the CEO of the Western Health Board today with the Secretary of my Department to discuss the development of health services in their board area. To a large extent Deputy Foxe's views are in line with our thinking on desirable developments as increased resources become available.

asked the Minister for Education, in respect of Carysfort College, County Dublin during the period between 1979 and its closure, or such shorter period before closure if circumstances require it, the amount of money which her Department have given by way of grant or aid of any kind in support of buildings and equipment; when her Department provided such funds; in each instance the specific purpose for which the funds were provided; and the arrangements under which the funds were provided with particular reference to the conditions under which her Department might be reimbursed.

asked the Minister for Education the reason no agreement was made between her Department and the Sisters of Mercy, to protect the State's investment at Carysfort College, County Dublin, and to ensure its return to the State in the event of the closure of the college.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 72 and 73 together. The information requested is detailed hereunder:—
1. Extension and Adaptation Works (including Furniture and Equipment) (1979-1981):—£1,801,673.69.

In June 1977 the Department wrote to the president of the college stating that in view of the level of State investment in the scheme of adaptation and extension to the college it was considered necessary to enter into a legal agreement to ensure that the college would be used as a training college or for some other approved educational purpose for as long as might be required by the Minister, or failing that, that State grants would be recouped in full or in part to the Department and be a first charge on the college premises. Details were requested as to legal titles etc., so that the necessary papers could be drawn up.

A draft deed of charge was drawn up by the Chief State Solicitor's office but protracted discussions ensued regarding certain aspects of the draft and the delineation of accompanying maps of the land owned by the Sisters. The document presented to the college authorities to secure repayment of funds advanced by the then Minister was not formally executed prior to notification of the college closure. At that stage the terms of the draft deed as envisaged would not have been appropriate to the revised circumstances and the matter was not pursued pending clarification of the future plans for the premises.
The Department are at present examining the situation in the light of the recent decision by the Sisters to sell the premises.
